risinfo.chaptertitle: 21. Interviewing Individuals at Risk for Suicide

sect1.title: Interviewing Individuals at Risk for Suicide

sect2.title: Description of the Problem
sect2.para: Suicide Suicide is a public health concern concern in the United States and abroad. The National Center for Health Statistics in the United States estimates that 49,449 individuals died by suicide in the United States in 2022, a three percent rise from the prior year (Curtin & Garnett, 2023 ). The twenty-first century has seen a rise in suicide rates in the United States. In the year 2000, population-level suicide rates were estimated to be 10.4 deaths for every 100,000 individuals; this rate has risen to 14.3 deaths for every 100,000 in 2022 (National Institute of Mental Health, 2024 ). While there were brief declines in the suicide rate between 2019 and 2020, the overall rates have rebounded and are now on the rise again, highlighting the clear need for evidence-based assessments and interventions.

Even greater than suicide deaths are the number of individuals who report experiencing serious thoughts of suicide. Upwards of 13 million adults in the United States report having had serious thoughts of suicide in the last year, and 1.6 million adults report attempting suicide in the last year (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, 2023 ). The rise in the incidence incidence of suicidal thoughts suicidal thoughts and behaviors has been linked to numerous social and economic risk factors such as a lack of access to mental health resources and financial strain (U. S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), 2024 ). In more recent years, research has demonstrated that suicidality disproportionately affects marginalized groups. For example, research has demonstrated that non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaskan Native persons are disproportionately represented in suicide statistics, with an estimated rate of 22.1 deaths for every 100,000 individuals (Stone et al., 2023 ). Suicide rates have also significantly increased in Black youth, rising by 19.2% from 2018 to 2021 (Stone et al., 2023 ). Additionally, LGBTQ+ youth are at four times greater risk of attempting suicide than their same-aged peers (The Trevor Project, 2023 ). When working with with individuals at risk for suicide, clinicians must be sensitive to the diverse risk factors that may influence an individual’s suicidal thoughts suicidal thoughts and behavior, a point that will be further discussed in this chapter.

While we cannot predict with any certainty whether an individual will die by suicide, an adept clinician can evaluate various risk factors and warning signs for suicidal risk (Tucker et al., 2015 ) along with protective factors during the interview process that can lead to an overall clinical formulation of relative risk. Moreover, the formulation of risk can be further supplemented by considerations of relative stability stability that can directly inform considerations of “clear and imminent” danger that potentially triggers more restrictive care (Jobes, 2023 ). The interview for suicidal risk can take many different forms depending upon the needs of the clinician and patient. There have been several attempts at routinized assessment over the years (e. g. Berman & Silverman, 2014 ; Chu et al., 2015 ; Shea, 2009 ; Silverman & Berman, 2014 ), each taking a systematic approach that includes assessment of one’s history of suicidal behavior, plans or intended method of suicide, access to lethal means, one’s experience of suicidal desire and intent, and other clinical risk factors (e. g., hopelessness, stressful life events). Bottom line, the ultimate goal of the assessment is to create a suicide risk formulation. Clearly, people who are suicidal are not identical; the formulation of relative risk is thus not an exercise in prediction as much as it reflects a level of clinical concern that can inform intervention (Berman & Silverman, 2014 ).

To create the basis for sound clinical judgment related to suicide risk, clinicians must be aware of the best practices for assessing suicide, and receive adequate training. Moreover, it is important that clinicians develop “usual and customary practices” in advance for working with individuals at risk (Jobes, 2020 ). Working with patients who are suicidal may be anxiety-provoking for clinicians without such training and expertise. In fact, such clinical practice may actually be unethical and could further put the patient at risk (Jobes & Barnett, 2024 ; Sommers-Flanagan & Sommers-Flanagan, 1995 ). The current chapter is thus a guide, offering concise and specific recommendations for interviewing individuals at risk for suicide, emphasizing the integrative use of evidence-based tools and semi-structured assessment approaches.

sect2.title: Procedures for Gathering Information
sect2.para: The process of gathering information from individuals at risk for suicide will vary greatly depending on the setting, amount of time allotted, and the clinician’s skill and preferences. In general, it is preferred that a combination of structured assessment tools and semi-structured or unstructured approaches be used when conducting an interview. The clinical interview clinical interview should answer basic questions related to the patient’s history and current experiences with suicidal thoughts suicidal thoughts , feelings, and behaviors. The following section highlights important domains for assessment. In addition to unstructured or semi-structured interviewing, clinicians should consider incorporating actuarial assessments (both self-report and clinician-administered) to aid in collecting further information. These instruments can meaningfully supplement the clinician’s interview and also add valuable documentation that reduces exposure to malpractice liability if there is an adverse outcome (Jobes & Barnett, 2024 ).
sect2.sect3:
Clinical Interview
The clinical interview clinical interview can be unstructured, semi-structured, or structured, depending on the needs of the clinician, patient, and resource or time limitations. Unstructured or semi-structured approaches allow for a greater degree of flexibility. Structured approaches may have the advantage of providing specific questions and prompts for the clinician to follow and may have greater reliability and validity. However, structured interviews have less flexibility, which could mean that important aspects of suicide risk remain unexplored. Regardless of the approach, it is important to ensure that a number of evidence-based risk and protective factors are assessed during the interview. These domains have been previously discussed by scholars, and are further adapted and outlined in detail below (e. g., Berman & Silverman, 2014 ; Bryan & Rudd, 2006 ; Chu et al., 2015 ; Fowler, 2012 ; Silverman & Berman, 2014 ).21.1Table 21.1 Within Within
Suicidal Thinking : The patient’s current experience of suicidal ideation and thoughts, including frequency, intensity, and duration.
Suicide Planning : The patient’s stated plans for suicide. This may include time, place, method, and access to means. Increased specificity of plans may indicate increased risk.
Suicide Preparation : Any steps the patient has already taken to prepare for suicide; This may include actions such as giving away belongings or accessing lethal means.
History of Behavior : The patient’s patient’s history of suicidal behaviors including time since occurrence, the frequency and context around previous behavior, and the lethality and method of any previous attempts or aborted attempts. Significantly greater risk is associated with anyone who has two or more suicide attempts.
Precipitating Stressors : Any recent precipitating factors such as significant losses (e. g., loss of a loved one, financial loss, loss of a relationship, or loss of identity), health problems, or relationship problems.
Other Symptoms : Any symptoms symptoms related to psychiatric diagnoses (depression, bipolar disorder, anxiety, schizophrenia, substance use disorder, etc.) and symptoms such as sadness, anhedonia, anxiety, fatigue, hopelessness, impulsivity, or a lack of self-control.
Protective Factors : Factors that may be protective against suicidal thoughts and behavior, such as the presence of social support, coping skills, reasons for living, religion or a sense of meaning in life, and active active participation in treatment.
Questions to guide assessment in risk factor domains domains
Domain of assessment
Example questions to ask
Suicidal Thinking
• Do you have thoughts of killing yourself or wanting to die?
• Do you have thoughts that others would be better off if you were dead?
• How often are you having these thoughts?
• How long do the thoughts last?
• Do you feel you can control these thoughts?
Suicide Planning
• Do you have a plan for suicide?
• Do you have a specific time or location for when and where you will kill yourself?
• Do you have a method(s) for how you will kill yourself?
• Do you have access to this/these method(s)?
• Do you know how to use these means?
Suicide Preparation
• Have you taken any steps to prepare for suicide?
• Have you acquired lethal means?
• Have you written a suicide note?
History of Behavior
• Have you ever attempted suicide before?
• How many times have you attempted suicide?
• Can you tell me about the most recent attempt?
• What method(s) did you use?
• What led up to the attempt?
• Have you ever had a plan to attempt suicide that was interrupted or stopped?
Precipitating Stressors
• Have you experienced any major losses recently (financial, loss of a loved one, loss of identity, or relationship)?
• Have you been experiencing any acute or chronic health problems?
• Have you been experiencing any relationship problems?
Other Symptoms
• Have you been diagnosed with any psychiatric disorders?
• Are you experiencing any depressive symptoms (anhedonia, depression, fatigue, trouble sleeping, sadness)?
• Do you use any substances?
• Do you feel hopeless?
Protective Factors
• Do you feel supported by friends or family members?
• How do you cope during difficult moments?
• What keeps you alive (reasons for living)?

sect3.title: Advantages and Disadvantages of Assessment Measures
sect3.para:
Of the instruments instruments listed in Table 21.2 , the ASQ ASQ and C-SSRS are noteworthy as they are both non-proprietary (readily available online) and are relatively easy to use (Jobes, 2023 ). The ASQ is a brief screening tool that can provide clinicians with a rapid identification of a patient’s possible risk of suicidal ideation and behaviors. The ASQ was originally developed for use with pediatric patients but has since been normed with adults and has been translated into many languages (Horowitz et al., 2020 ). While its brevity is an advantage, it does not delve deeply into more questions about suicide planning or preparation. The National Institute of Mental Health offers a “toolkit” for using the ASQ at the following link:
https://​www.​nimh.​nih.​gov/​research/​research-conducted-at-nimh/​asq-toolkit-materials
.

The remaining assessment instruments that we are highlighting—the PHQ-9 PHQ-9 and SITBI SITBI —are somewhat less cited within the the literature but still have the ability to provide useful information to supplement clinical interview assessment data. The PHQ-9 (a depression screening measure) is widely used in the field in part because it is non-proprietary and there are data for its value to identify potential suicidal risk (Simon et al., 2016 ). However, the PHQ-9 has the disadvantage of only including one conflated question (i. e., “Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself”) related to suicide. Importantly, other research has shown that the PHQ-9 PHQ-9 can miss patients who are suicidal, fundamentally undermining its value as a suicide assessment (Mournet et al., 2021 ).

The SITBI is the longest of the highlighted instruments, assessing a wide array of risk variables and characteristics related to self-injurious thoughts and behavior. While the SITBI SITBI has the advantage of providing a wealth of information related to suicidal thoughts suicidal thoughts and behaviors, it leaves less room for flexibility in assessment and and may have more utility within clinical research.

sect2.title: Recommendations for Formal Assessment
sect2.para: Such competencies competencies include discussions of an individual’s suicidality experience (e. g., establishing their presenting problem, risk and protective factors, degree of intent, history of behavior, and any preparation), symptom management (e. g., safety planning, lethal means restriction, treatments, and strategies), and other important considerations (e. g., ethical and legal, such as confidentiality and proper documentation). These competencies can be ensured by using the aforementioned assessment tools along with self-report structured and semi-structured interviewing which can also be meaningfully supplemented by collateral information (i. e., with the patient’s permission, obtaining information from family and close friends).

First and foremost, formal assessments for suicidality must rely on validated procedures in the given setting and population clinicians work within. A suicide risk assessment must be adapted for its immediate context. The assessment process is going to differ between virtual and in-person settings, emergency departments and outpatient practices, and research and community settings. Regardless of the environment, formal assessments must be consistent in their acceptability, feasibility, and adherence to best practices.

The procedures outlined previously can be used to help identify individuals who are open to directly expressing their suicidality risk. The reality is that not all individuals who experience suicidality directly communicate or endorse suicidal intent, with some even actively concealing their experiences (Podlogar & Joiner, 2020 ). In such cases, there can be indirect communications and behaviors that may suggest potential suicidal risk. Such communications communications can be conscious or may be unconscious but nevertheless provide indications that may reflect intention and increased risk therein (e. g., preparatory behaviors, help-rejecting, and hopelessness). This underscores the importance of listening to what the patient overtly says but what also may be inferred through certain behaviors or vague comments. For example, a provider should pay close attention and follow-up when a patient off-handedly says “what’s the point?” or “things just never work out for me” or “I just need the pain to end!”

The importance of an empathic approach empathic approach to assessing suicidal risk cannot be over-stated. Indeed, the “ Aeschi Approach ” in the 2000s was a movement that focused on the merits of an empathic and non-judgmental approach to forming alliances with patients who were suicidal (Michel & Jobes, 2011 ). The Aeschi movement was decidedly not a “medical model” approach to suicide, emphasizing a patient-centered and narrative approach that was featured in ten international conferences and an edited book. By adopting an empathetic approach, clinicians can thus create an optimal and validating relationship that is free from judgment and stigma.

Despite professional guidance, increased scrutiny, and updated guidelines guidelines (such as the APA’s lengthy 2020 guide), recent studies underscore the issue of patient nondisclosure or concealment within formal assessment practices. For example example , Hallford et al.’ ( 2023 ) meta-analysis showed that in comparison to family and friends, participants were much less inclined to disclose their suicidal risk to healthcare professionals. A recent qualitative study recruiting individuals who had previously attempted suicide highlighted various reasons behind suicidality concealment such as fear of stigma, involuntary treatment, and invasion of privacy (Sheehan et al., 2019 ). To combat nondisclosure nondisclosure , Podlogar and Joiner ( 2020 ) recommend that clinicians prioritize a patient-centered approach, which should immediately foster hope and provide validation. Patients should be encouraged to share their experiences in their own words and be active collaborators in their treatment planning and intervention outcomes. A supportive clinician-patient alliance is key to accurate suicide screening and treatment (Knapp, 2020 ).

An important goal of goal of suicide risk assessments is to help better inform and guide clinical case management and treatment planning such that suicidal suffering can be decreased and patients become more stable and able to manage any suicidal thoughts or feelings (Jobes, 2023 ). Clinicians should be mindful that the assessment of suicidal risk provides valuable information for effective treatment planning that better informs safety planning and stabilization as well as setting the stage for effective suicide-focused treatment (Jobes & Barnett, 2024 ). Formal assessments should not be a one-time occurrence, but rather a continued and evolving assessment process in which individuals are provided an opportunity to fine-tune their responses concurrent to their self-exploration within the course of clinical treatment.
